events.originalText: Prayut Chan-o-cha, the commander-in-chief of the Royal Thai Army, launched a coup d'état against the caretaker government following six months of political crisis.
events.subtitle: Prayut Chan-o-cha
events.headline: Thai Army Chief Launches Coup Against Caretaker Government

events.originalText: Upon landing in Mangalore, Air India Express Flight 812 overshot the runway and fell down a hillside, killing 158 of the 166 people on board.
events.subtitle: Mangalore
events.headline: Air India Express Flight 812 Crashes in Mangalore, 158 Dead

events.originalText: Police announced that the skeletal remains of Federal Bureau of Prisons intern Chandra Levy, who had been missing for a year, had been found in Rock Creek Park in Washington, D.C.
events.subtitle: Federal Bureau of Prisons
events.headline: Remains of Missing BOP Intern Chandra Levy Found in Rock Creek Park

events.originalText: In Public Prosecutor v Taw Cheng Kong, the Court of Appeal of Singapore overruled a High Court decision that was the only time a statute in Singapore had been ruled unconstitutional.
events.subtitle: Public Prosecutor v Taw Cheng Kong
events.headline: Singapore Court Overrules High Court Decision on Unconstitutional Statute

events.originalText: During Hindu–Muslim rioting in Meerut, India, 19 members of the Provincial Armed Constabulary allegedly massacred 42 Muslims and dumped their bodies in water canals.
events.subtitle: Religious violence in India
events.headline: Provincial Armed Constabulary Allegedly Massacres 42 Muslims in Meerut

events.originalText: Location testing for Pac-Man, a Japanese arcade game that became an icon of 1980s popular culture, began in Shibuya, Tokyo.
events.subtitle: Pac-Man
events.headline: Pac-Man Location Testing Begins in Shibuya, Tokyo

events.originalText: The Dominion of Ceylon changed its name to Sri Lanka, adopted a new constitution, and officially became a republic within the Commonwealth.
events.subtitle: Dominion of Ceylon
events.headline: Dominion of Ceylon Changes Name to Sri Lanka and Becomes Republic

events.originalText: The most powerful earthquake ever recorded, registering approximately 9.5 Mw, struck near Valdivia, Chile, generating tsunamis that reached Hawaii and Japan.
events.subtitle: 1960 Valdivia earthquake
events.headline: Powerful Earthquake Strikes Valdivia, Chile, Generating Tsunamis

events.originalText: Ethnic riots mostly targeting the minority Sri Lankan Tamils broke out in Ceylon, resulting in at least 158 deaths over the next few days.
events.subtitle: 1958 anti-Tamil pogrom
events.headline: Ethnic Riots Erupt in Ceylon, Resulting in 158 Deaths

events.originalText: Germany and Italy signed the Pact of Steel, a military and political alliance.
events.subtitle: Pact of Steel
events.headline: Germany and Italy Sign Pact of Steel

events.originalText: California's Lassen Peak violently erupted, the only volcanic eruption in the contiguous U.S. in the 20th century until Mount St. Helens erupted in 1980.
events.subtitle: Lassen Peak
events.headline: Lassen Peak Erupts in California, Only Volcanic Eruption in 20th Century

events.originalText: Sultan Abdul Hamid II established the Ullah millet, a separate millet for the Aromanians within the Ottoman Empire.
events.subtitle: Abdul Hamid II
events.headline: Sultan Abdul Hamid II Establishes Ullah Millet for Aromanians

events.originalText: The first Blackwall Tunnel under the River Thames was opened to improve commerce and trade in the East End of London.
events.subtitle: Blackwall Tunnel
events.headline: First Blackwall Tunnel Opens in London

events.originalText: Senator Charles Sumner (pictured) was assaulted by Representative Preston Brooks in the United States Senate chamber in retaliation for a speech in which Sumner fiercely criticized slaveholders.
events.subtitle: Charles Sumner
events.headline: Senator Charles Sumner Assaulted in U.S. Senate Chamber

events.originalText: Abraham Lincoln was issued a patent for an invention to lift boats over obstacles in a river, making him the only U.S. president ever to hold a patent.
events.subtitle: Abraham Lincoln
events.headline: Abraham Lincoln Issued Patent for Boat-Lifting Invention

events.originalText: In Shiraz, Iran, the Báb declared himself to be a messenger of God to Mullá Husayn, leading to the foundation of Bábism, considered to be a precursor to the Baháʼí Faith.
events.subtitle: Shiraz
events.headline: Báb Declares Himself Messenger of God in Shiraz, Iran

events.originalText: HMS Beagle departed on her first voyage from Plymouth for a hydrographic survey of the Patagonia and Tierra del Fuego regions of South America.
events.subtitle: HMS Beagle
events.headline: HMS Beagle Departs on First Voyage for South America Survey

events.originalText: A riot broke out in Littleport, England, over high unemployment and rising grain costs, spreading to Ely the next day before being quelled by troops.
events.subtitle: Ely and Littleport riots of 1816
events.headline: Riot Breaks Out in Littleport, England, Over Unemployment

events.originalText: An earthquake registering an estimated 7.1 Ms struck Constantinople and was followed by a tsunami that caused significant damage.
events.subtitle: 1766 Istanbul earthquake
events.headline: Earthquake and Tsunami Strike Constantinople, Causing Damage

events.originalText: The Trevi Fountain (pictured) in Rome was officially inaugurated by Pope Clement XIII.
events.subtitle: Trevi Fountain
events.headline: Trevi Fountain in Rome Inaugurated by Pope Clement XIII

events.originalText: Albrecht von Wallenstein and King Christian IV of Denmark signed the Treaty of Lübeck to end Danish intervention in the Thirty Years' War.
events.subtitle: Albrecht von Wallenstein
events.headline: Treaty of Lübeck Signed to End Danish Intervention in Thirty Years' War

events.originalText: Arab–Byzantine wars: The Byzantine navy began a raid on the Nile Delta port city of Damietta, whose garrison was absent at the time.
events.subtitle: Arab–Byzantine wars
events.headline: Byzantine Navy Raids Damietta in Arab-Byzantine Wars
